column1: Bellevue ( BEL-vyoo) is a city in the Eastside region of King County
column3: United States
column4: located across Lake Washington from Seattle. It is the third-largest city in the Seattle metropolitan area and has variously been characterized as an edge city
column5: a suburb
column6: boomburb
column7: or satellite city. Its population was 122
column9: 164 in a 2019 census estimate. The city's name is derived from the French term belle vue ("beautiful view").Bellevue is home to some of the world's most innovative technology companies. Prior to 2008
column10: its downtown area underwent rapid change with many high-rise projects being constructed
column11: and was relatively unaffected by the economic downturn. Downtown Bellevue is currently the second-largest city center in Washington state
column17: 200 residents. Based on per capita income
column18: the city is the sixth-wealthiest of 522 communities in the state of Washington.In 2008
column19: Bellevue was number one in CNNMoney's list of the best places to live and launch a business
column20: and in 2010 was again ranked as the fourth-best place to live in America. In 2014
column21: Bellevue was ranked as the second-best place to live by USA Today. More than 145 companies have been located in Bellevue; companies currently headquartered there include PACCAR Inc

column3: maintained a small outpost settlement called Satskal (SAH-tsah-kahl) along the Mercer Slough
column4: south of present day downtown Bellevue. It was from this village that an attack on the settlers of Elliott Bay was staged from. The Duwamish also had a village near Factoria called 'pah-pah-DEEL'.Bellevue was first settled by European Americans in 1869 by William Meydenbauer and Aaron Mercer
column5: who claimed homestead tracts several miles apart. Both moved away within a few years
column6: and permanent residents did not arrive until 1879. By 1882 a community
column8: had established itself. Once the land had been logged
column10: largely by Japanese immigrant labor in the early 20th century
column11: to support small scale farming on leased land plots.By the early part of the 20th century
column12: Bellevue had acquired a reputation as a weekend getaway destination for Seattle residents
column13: who would arrive by ferry at Meydenbauer Bay and spend the day at nearby Wildwood Park. After the ferry landing was moved to Medina
column15: tourism to Bellevue waned. To counter this decline
column16: the Bellevue Strawberry Festival was conceived of in 1925
column17: and by the 1930s it had grown to attract as many as 15
column19: Bellevue was still a small town with around 2
column20: 000 residents.Prior to the opening of the Lake Washington Floating Bridge in 1940
column21: Bellevue was mostly rural farmland area with little development. Although it was small
column22: developers were pushing to change that; in the 1920s
column23: James S. Ditty predicted that it would become a city with a population of 200
column24: 000. He envisioned plans that included the bridging of Lake Washington and an area filled with golf courses and airports. His map with these visions was published in 1928. Once the Murrow Memorial Bridge opened
column26: and the area began to evolve into a bedroom community.In 1942
column27: the Bellevue Strawberry Festival was cancelled. The primary reason was that some 90 percent of the agricultural workforce in the area was of Japanese ancestry
column28: and all of these farmers and their families had been forcibly interned in camps following the start of World War II. The fair would not be revived for another 45 years. Following the expulsion of the ethnic Japanese farming community
column29: a large quantity of farmland became available for development. This made way for the initial development of the Bellevue downtown area.

column1: Bellevue incorporated as a third-class city on the March 21
column2: 1953. Following the 1963 opening of a second bridge across the lake
column3: the Evergreen Point Floating Bridge
column4: the city began to grow more rapidly. The Crossroads community was annexed in 1964. Lake Hills was annexed in 1969. By the 1970 census
column5: Bellevue had become the fourth most populous city in the state of Washington
column6: following only Seattle
column8: and Tacoma.Bellevue remains one of the largest cities in the state
column9: with several high-rise structures in its core and a burgeoning business community. The city experienced a building boom during the mid 2000s
column10: with the building of developments such as Lincoln Square and the Bravern.Reflective of Bellevue's growth over the years is Bellevue Square
column11: now one of the largest shopping centers in the region. Opened in 1946
column12: the mall has undergone several significant phases of expansion since the 1980s.

column1: The city's plans include the Bel-Red Corridor Project
column2: a large-scale planning effort to encourage the redevelopment of the large Bel-Red section of the city bordering the adjacent town of Redmond which is a major employment area in the city. Patterned after what planners consider the successful redevelopment of the downtown core
column3: plans include superblock mixed-use projects similar to Lincoln Square
column4: premised on private construction and the development of infrastructure such as the extension of Link Light Rail to the Eastside.

column1: Bellevue lies between Lake Washington to the west and the smaller Lake Sammamish to the east. Much of Bellevue is drained by the Kelsey Creek watershed
column2: whose source is located in the Larsen and Phantom Lake green belt and whose outlet is near where Interstate 90 meets Lake Washington's eastern shore. The city is bisected by Interstate 405 running north–south
column3: and the southern portion is crossed from west to east by Interstate 90. The State Route 520 freeway roughly delineates the upper reaches of Bellevue.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 36.47 square miles (94.46 km2)
column3: of which
column4: 31.97 square miles (82.80 km2) is land and 4.50 square miles (11.65 km2) is water.The city's name is derived from a French term for "beautiful view". Under favorable weather conditions
column5: scenic vistas of the Olympic Mountains and Cascade Mountains can be viewed from hilltops (and strategically positioned high-rise buildings) within the incorporated city.

column1: Bellevue is bordered by the cities of Kirkland to the north and Redmond to the northeast along the Overlake and Crossroads neighborhoods. Across the short East Channel Bridge
column2: I-90 connects Bellevue to Mercer Island to the southwest. Issaquah is to the east
column3: down I-90 at the south end of Lake Sammamish. The city is bordered to the west by many affluent suburbs such as Medina
column4: Clyde Hill
column5: Hunts Point and Yarrow Point. The south end of Bellevue is bordered by the city of Renton
column6: and to the southeast
column7: the relatively recently incorporated city of Newcastle.

column1: Like much of the Puget Sound lowland
column2: Bellevue has a mild oceanic climate. It also has frequent rain showers from October to May
column3: with precipitation levels typically being over 2 inches (51 mm). On average
column4: the hottest month is July
column5: while January is the coldest.

column1: Bellevue is the main Eastside hub for both the local transit authority
column3: and Sound Transit
column4: the regional transit system. The Bellevue Transit Center
column5: which serves both Metro and Sound buses
column6: is located in the heart of the downtown business district and is connected to Interstate 405 by NE 6th St. and a direct-access Texas T HOV ramp. Local buses run into Kirkland
column10: and the University District; regional buses go to Bothell
column16: among other cities.The East Link light rail line is planned to run from Seattle through Mercer Island and Bellevue before ending in Redmond. It was approved by voters on November 4
column18: as part of the Sound Transit 2 ballot measure. It began construction in 2015 and is scheduled to begin service in 2023.

column1: The Bellevue City Council lobbied hard for Sound Transit—a regional transit authority—to construct its light-rail line underground through Bellevue's rapidly growing downtown. Bellevue promised to devote between $104 million to $150 million toward a potential tunnel in the form of cash
column3: free access to rights-of-way and one-time tax revenues that result from the East Link project. In November 2011
column4: the council signed an agreement with Sound Transit. Tunnel construction started in early 2016 while the remainder of downtown Bellevue construction began in mid-2017. Former Bellevue City Council member Claudia Balducci is a member of the Sound Transit board of directors.

column1: The City of Bellevue has undertaken an extensive "Bel-Red Area Transformation" process which seeks to plan some 900 acres (3.6 km2) in the Spring District in the city's northern portion
column2: all of which is premised on the extension of light rail to the Eastside under Sound Transit 2. The top-down and highly integrated land use and transportation planning is similar to earlier planning for the Downtown.

column1: Bellevue was also served by a railroad
column2: a Burlington Northern branch line known as the Woodinville Subdivision
column3: which included the historic Wilburton Trestle. This local freight line was the subject of debate over whether to railbank the line and construct a multi-purpose trail. As of March 2009
column4: the Port of Seattle had to postpone its acquisition of the corridor because of instability in the bond market. As of 2016 the line is disused however part of the track bed at Wilburton Station will be reused by Sound Transit's light-rail construction.The city once had an operating airfield named Bellevue Airfield.

column1: Bellevue has a council-manager form of government with seven non-partisan council members elected at large for staggered four-year terms. The City Council selects a Mayor from among its members (not by popular vote)
column2: who serves as council chair for two years but has no veto power. As of 2020
column3: the mayor is Lynne Robinson and the deputy mayor is Jared Nieuwenhuis. The mayor administrates council meetings
column4: helps set the issues on the council's meeting agendas
column5: and serves as the city's most visible spokesperson. Operational authority is held by the city manager
column6: who administers the city's day-to-day activities. The city manager is also elected by the seven members of the council instead of by popular vote.

column1: Politically the city leans strongly Democratic much like the Seattle/King County area as a whole. Of the 61
column2: 742 residents who cast ballots in the 2016 U.S. presidential election
column3: 66.11% voted for Hillary Clinton compared to 24.58% for Donald Trump.

column1: The city is served by the Bellevue School District. There are four main public high schools – Bellevue High School
column3: Newport High School
column4: and Sammamish High School – as well as two choice lottery high schools
column5: International School and Big Picture School. Newsweek's 2015 ranking of U.S. public high schools placed Interlake at #359 and Newport at #391
column6: with both schools noted for equitably helping low-income students meet average scores on standardized tests. Portions of Bellevue also lie within the boundaries of Lake Washington School District
column7: Renton School District and Issaquah School District. At the higher education level the city is home to Bellevue College
column8: part of the Washington Community and Technical Colleges system.

column1: Bellevue is home to Open Window School

column1: Bellevue is an economic hub of the Seattle region's Eastside and home to the headquarters of various sizes
column2: including the U.S. operations for many international firms. Since 2005
column3: the city has become a hub for software engineering and other technology development centers. These include Expedia
column4: PACCAR Inc
column5: T-Mobile US
column6: Eddie Bauer
column8: and Symetra. Bellevue hosts a number of satellite offices for large technology companies such as eBay
column12: and Microsoft; Microsoft was at one point headquartered in Bellevue but has since moved to the neighboring community of Redmond
column13: Washington. Celebrated video game companies Valve
column16: and The Pokémon Company are also based here.

column1: Bellevue is the site of the popular annual Bellevue Arts and Crafts Fair (originally Pacific Northwest Arts and Crafts Fair)
column2: held since 1947 the last weekend in July. The biennial Bellevue Sculpture Exhibition draws thousands of visitors to the Downtown Park to view up to 46 three-dimensional artworks from artists around the country. In celebration of its strawberry farming history
column3: Bellevue holds an annual Strawberry Festival on the fourth weekend in June at Crossroads Park. The festival initially began in 1925
column4: and continued to 1942 when many Bellevue's strawberry farmers were incarcerated as part of the Japanese Internment. In 1987 the festival was resumed as a one evening event
column5: and in 2003 it was expanded back to a multi-day festival.

column1: The Bellevue Arts Museum first opened in 1975
column2: then moved to Bellevue Square in 1983. In 2001
column3: the museum moved into its own building
column4: designed by Steven Holl. The museum subsequently ran into financial difficulties and was forced to close to the public in 2003. After a lengthy fundraising campaign
column5: a remodel
column6: and a new mission to become a national center for the fine art of craft and design
column8: 2005 with an exhibition of teapots. The Rosalie Whyel Museum of Doll Art - now closed - contained one of the largest doll collections in the world—more than a thousand dolls—displayed on two floors of a Victorian-style building
column9: which is now the site of the KidsQuest Children's Museum. Near Interstate 405 is Meydenbauer Center
column10: a convention center that brings corporate meetings and charity events to the downtown area. Meydenbauer also includes a 410-seat theater which attracts operas
column12: and orchestral performances.The city government has planned to build a performing arts center

column14: since the 1980s. It would include a 2
column17: and creative spaces at a site in Downtown Bellevue. The $200 million project is partially funded with private donations and grants from the city and county governments.
